== Desktop Applets ==

Obviously, the latest fad in desktops apart from 3D are the desktop applets (Windows sidebar, Mac Widgets, Konfabulator...) As far as I know these are available on Gnome as well (Gdesklets?), but they are not installed by default nor promoted. I think some effort should be made towards providing similar applets as the commercial OSs.

-Sadly, Gdesklets are full of memoryleaks and are of questionable quality. After trying to like them for a few months, I uninstalled them all. Though still very new, you might take a look at Jackfield: http://www.kryogenix.org/code/jackfield/
* There should be some form of widgets, as people are going to be used to having them in Vista and OS X. Compiz Fusion also has an integrated "widget layer" similar to OS X's Dashboard. --maccam94
* Screenlets are a good option, and it works with compiz (it only works with compiz, or beryl) --brodock
** One issue with Screenlets is that if compiz crashes, the widgets become visible and tend to cover the screen

== Cute console ==
Suse, Mandriva and Gentoo have a nice framebuffered console with a graphical background and higher resolution than standard console. I know that Ubuntu tries to make it's users not use console if they don't need to, but maybe we could put it as an option to turn on manually? -- AzraelNightwalker

== Theme ==
I think a less-than-abstract desktop background would be nice. Something with a real picture in it, that people can connect to and associate with Ubuntu. XP had the rolling green hill. Fedora 7 has a flight theme. Ubuntu needs something other than shades of brown. I have heard people comment the color scheme, but a background with a single color has become rather boring. Since Gutsy will also include composite by default, other graphics should be made as well (better cube tops, a skydome, animated splash, etc). With composite, should also come gloss and transparency in window elements. This would create a cleaner, more modern look. --maccam94

== Instant load of the desktop ==
When Gnome loads at the bootup, it sequentially loads each part of the desktop. For example, the user first sees the background image, then the gnome-panel, then the icons... But the desktop isn't usable until it has been completely loaded. For instance, during the load process you can't click on the panel icons, and this would give a negative impression on some users.

I suggest then to hide the whole desktop until it has been completely loaded and it is operational with some kind of progress bar or image.

* Make the themes available in G-A-I. And rename G-A-I from "Add Remove" into "Add-ons" (more intriguing and more in line with FF).

* Make the panel work like Firefox toolbar. Firefox toolbar has a nice interface as far as the toolbar goes. There is only one item in the menu: "customize", after that it is all drag and drop and things go easily in the right position. Compare this with the gnome panel where shortcut menu is cluttered with customization items (add, remove, move, lock...), an akward locking mechanism, things move "continuously" and you can end up with blank spaces between items. 
** Enlightenment 0.17 has a similar technique, where a menu entry (something like "Edit Mode") gives everything resize handles and makes them draggable when clicked on, regardless of their usual clickableness (is that a word?). Also, Kicker has the option to not show handles unless the mouse is over the widget/applet, which seems to be a more intuitive way of handling (excuse the pun) applets, as GNOME's handles often go unnoticed since they hang around all of the time. Also, if handles are going to be used at all then any "lock" or "cutomise" mode is made pretty much irrelevant, since the handles become mostly useless when "lock" is on or "customise" isn't (if this idea will simplify applet's right-click menus then a single menu can be used across the whole applet [I am thinking of the window list here] rather than the applet's controls only being accessible from the handle), so either use a "customise" mode, or keep the handles as an always-on customise mode (I think the "lock to panel" toggle should be done away with anyway, unless it is sorted out to actually do what it says. Try locking a load of application launchers to a non-expanded panel and log out and in a few times, you'll see they keep getting rearranged when they are supposed to be locked in place, and reorganising them to their correct locations is made more difficult by having to unlock all of the launchers first!))
